items.title: Safari adds over 100 new features
items.content:
#â€‹586 â€” March 29, 2023 | Read on the web

WebKit Features in Safari 16.4 â€” This is a mammoth release, adding 135(!) new features including support for Web Push, a slew of new CSS properties (including margin-trim), Declarative Shadow DOM support, iframe lazy-loading support, devtool changes, and the typical bug fixes. WebKit team member Jen Simmons said:

â€œItâ€™s hard to express just how massive a release Safari 16.4 is for web developers. Last night, I was reading replies web developers posted on Twitter back in 2021, when I asked what developers need most from WebKit â€” and the vast majority of things you asked for have now shipped.â€
Plenty of progress has been made, so it's well worth checking out to bring yourself up to speed on whatâ€™sÂ new.
  • Safari 16.4 Release Notes
    â†³ The full, formal release notes outlining what's new in bulletpointÂ form.

What We Can All Learn from Web PerformanceÂ Leaders â€” Case studies from companies like Airbnb, Pinterest, BBC, Zillow, Casper, Shopify, and Leroy Merlin. Learn how they speed up their sites, use performance budgets, create a culture of performance, and measure the impact of site speed on theirÂ business.

SpeedCurve sponsor

Visually Hidden Content is a 'Hack' That Needs to Be Resolved, Not Enshrined â€” In issue 583 we shared Ben Myers piece on why he believes the web needs a native .visually-hidden HTML/CSS technique. Here, Scott shares his take: â€œwhile there is a common ruleset for visually hiding content, codifying that to me seems more of a silent acknowledgement that a hack is the best we can do. I donâ€™t agree. The web should be better thanÂ thatâ€.

Scott O'Hara

The Ultimate Guide to Image Optimization â€” Image optimization is the web performance â€˜lowest hanging fruitâ€™. Hereâ€™s a sound look at how to optimise imagery without sacrificing itsÂ quality.

Karolina Szczur

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Good news!Â Push notifications are now supported cross-browser in the three most common browser engines.

  • The first Safari 16.5 Beta is out now with support for CSS Nesting.

  • Did you know some home appliances have a 'Sabbath mode'? Eric Bailey explains, and notes how such a practice may translate to digital experiences.

  • Back in October of last year we shared how Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡ was embarking on a journey to learn modern CSS bits over the course of 100 days. That journey came to an end last month.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Improving CSS Shapes with Trigonometric Functions â€” This is an excellent dive into how we can use trigonometric functions to simplify how we approach making regular polygons and how to use these new CSS powers to build even more complex shapes by approximating curves. Lots of code examples and demos hereÂ too.

Dan Wilson

â±ï¸ A few weeks back we shared this fun look at using trigonometry functions to create a working clock.

Health Benefits of Browser Diversity â€” With rumblings that Apple may be opening up the iOS ecosystem to other browser engines, and the positive progress the WebKit team are taking with Safari (see above), Tim is optimistic that â€œa pivot in strategy from Apple could open up so many doors to a healthierÂ webâ€.

Tim Kadlec

Yes-Code Automation with Retool Workflows â€” A fastest way to create intelligent, code-first integrations across your entire data stack. No extra infraÂ required.

Retool sponsor

CSS-Only Widgets Are Inaccessible â€” Notes that any claim that a CSS-only interactive widget is accessible â€œis probablyÂ wrongâ€.

Adrian Roselli

File Uploads for the Web: Uploading Files with HTML â€” The first post in a series all about uploading files to the web â€” this post, covers the steps needed to upload files using only HTML. The second covers JavaScript. Austin tells us more are on the way, looking at architecture planning, performance, security, andÂ more.

Austin Gil

Why APCA as a New Contrast Method? â€” This document isnâ€™t new, but it popped up on our radar this week â€” itâ€™s a solid intro/overview of the Accessible Perceptual Contrast Algorithm, a proposed solution for handling readability contrast in WCAG 3.0 and beyond. RelatedÂ repo.

#â€‹584 â€” March 15, 2023 | Read on the web

Ten Tips for Better CSS Transitions and Animations â€” An engaging and practical look at the things learnt about crafting transitions and animations on the web. Good, sound tipsÂ here.

Josh Collinsworth

Headless CMS with World-Class TypeScript Support â€” Kontent.ai is the leading platform for modular content. Streamline your code using TypeScript SDK, CLI, Rich text resolver, and strongly typed model generator. Scale with no problems when your project grows. Have you seen ourÂ UI?

Kontent.ai sponsor

SPA View Transitions Land in Chrome 111 â€” The View Transition API (currently only in Chrome) allows animated page transitions within single-page apps, and will later include multiâ€‘pageÂ apps. This could save a lot ofÂ work.

Jake Archibald (Chrome Developers)

â€œDesign First, Then Buildâ€: Letâ€™s Bury This Myth Forevermore â€” Waiting to build your mobile or web app after all the mockups and designs are complete is an increasingly obsolete model. This post presents an alternativeÂ approach.

Roman Shamin & Travis Turner

  • Unsure where/when you may use these, but here's the many different cursor types you may see when using macOS.

  • The Android team announced a privacy feature trial that will affect the use of the X-Requested-With header in request headers sent by WebViews.

  • A visual look back at the first versions of some popular Web services (e.g. Dribbble, Webflow, Stripe, GitHub, ProductÂ Hunt).

Mads Stoumann

Cosima Mielke

Whiskey Web and Whatnot sponsorpodcast

Relative Rounded Corners â€” If youâ€™ve got a rounded corner on both the outside and inside of an element, both with the same value, it can look odd. This post digs into the math and shares a formula to get 'relative' rounded corners, along with a CSS utility to apply to yourÂ projects.

Andy Bell

How to Change Favicon Upon Switching Browser Tabs â€” Originally inspired by Astro, you can see the concept at work on notepad.js.org

Amit Merchant

Rendering Patterns for Web Apps: Server-Side, Client-Side, and SSG Explained â€” A good explainer of the different options available in many Jamstack frameworks. It even dives into differed rendering (ISR), islands and streaming SSR as well as the pros and cons of each renderingÂ method.

GermÃ¡n Cocca

Beautiful and Mind-Bending Effects with WebGL RenderÂ Targets â€” Learn how to use WebGL Render Targets to create post-processing effects, optical illusions, and transition effects in React ThreeÂ projects.

Maxime Heckel

â–¶Â Â Coding Kenta Toshikuraâ€™s 'Glass Effect' with Three.js â€” More creative noodling with Three.js andÂ shaders.

Yuri Artiukh

Making Calendars with Accessibility and Internationalization in Mind
Mads Stoumann

What Leonardo Da Vinci Can Teach Us About Web Design
Frederick Oâ€™Brien

Embetty 4.0: Show Third Party Embeds Without Compromising Privacy â€” Tweets, and Facebook, Video or YouTube thumbnails (see demo here.) The privacy comes from using a proxy server you hostÂ yourself.

heise online

MiniSearch: Small In-Memory Fulltext Search Engine for Browser and Node â€” The strength of this solution is that the data from which it fetches is stored locally, thus allowing it to work offline and has goodÂ performance. Here's a liveÂ demo.

Luca Ongaro

css-variable: A Tiny Treeshakable Library to Define CSS Custom Properties in JS â€” Compatible with popular CSS-in-JS libraries like Emotion, styled-components, Linaria, etc., and it boasts better CSS minification and smaller virtual DOM updates, among otherÂ features.

Jan Nicklas

Tuple, a Lightning-Fast Pairing Tool Built for RemoteÂ Developers

Tuple sponsor
